captions.text: At the end of my video on misconceptions,
I mentioned the supposed fact that people swallow 8 spiders a year while sleeping,
but unlike the other misconceptions in that video which I explained away,
I turned this one into a cheap joke and left it at that.
This wasn't because it's true, but because the story behind that myth turns out to be a bit of a mystery.
The first place that I remember coming across the 8 Spiders fact was years ago on the lid of a Snapple can.
Snapple used to print facts of dubious value on their drinks, and though they've tried to hide it,
The Wayback Machine reveals that, "8 Spiders," was one of them.
Take a trip to Snopes.com, the go-to site for debunking urban legends of all kinds,
and, sure enough, the 8-Spiders-A-Year thing is listed.
Scroll down and Snopes says the story comes from Lisa Holst in 1993, when email was still fairly new
for most people and messages with subjects like:
RE:RE:FWD:RE:RE:FWD: AMAZING FACTS!!
were a higher proportion of network traffic.
Lisa Holst, says Snopes, wrote an article called, "Reading is Believing," in PC Professional, listing all kinds of made up facts that people would believe,

and 8-Spiders-A-Year was one of them.
This, I thought,
was the perfect misconception to finish the video, like a little moral on why you should be less credulous.
Out of interest, I went looking for the article to see what other fake facts she mentioned,
but Googling for her brought up nothing.
Well, not literarily nothing, but nothing helpful; moslty it's other articles debunking the 8-Spiders myth
using the exact same language as the Snopes article, which looks suspicious.
Intrigued, I contacted Snopes myself about their source, but got back a formed reply.
I don't know if ignoring their contact form is their usual way of doing business,
along with copy-paste blocking and pop-under-ads,
but it seemed odd for a site dedicated to exposing the truth.
Further digging yielded other articles about people like myself, trying to find Lisa Holst and verify Snopes' version of the story.
There's a page on Metafilter and Stack Exchange and even a website called eightspiders.com that went looking for her.
The guy who runs that last one even went so far as to contact the Library of Congress, who said they didn't know of any magazine called, "PC Professional."
Which leaves us in an odd, XKCD kind-of mood about Snopes.
If the Lisa Holst-version of the story is real, then why can't anyone find any record of her or her article?
And, if it's not real, is it just a mistake on Snopes' part?
If so, why haven't they replied to any of the people who brought it to their attention?
Or, perhaps we've gone through the looking glass, and the Lisa-Holst-made-up-the-8-Spiders-fact IS the myth,
promulgated by none other that Snopes themselves.
It wouldn't be the first time, as Snopes does have a purposely fake article on the site claiming that Mr. Ed was actually a zebra.
I wasn't able to go any further than this, but if you happen to know anything about Lisa Holst or the deal with Snopes,
please feel free to get in touch.

title: Looking for Lisa Holst (Re: 10 Misconceptions Rundown)

comments.text:
at 0:42 he says ''...Lisa Holst said snopes wrote an article...'',

comments.author: Toby John Scanlon

comments.text:
Lisa Holst was actually doing an experiment on the transmission of false 
data and crafted the spider factoid.  Much to her dismay, when she released 
a correction revealing that it was all an experiment, the less dramatic 
correction did not spread as much as the dramatic fact.

I just wish I remembered where I learned that.﻿

+Xah Lee This does not confirm that it's fake, it just confirms that Snopes 
gets TRILLIONS of emails every year from people claiming they're trying to 
pull the hood over someone's head (typically someone who lied on the 
internet and got caught by snopes) and filter all their mail of anything 
about wrong articles that isn't coming from their own moderators or 
contributers.

It DOES confirm that this is a mystery, and so has an answer that we don't 
know and can either look for or pretend to know (even though we don't) and 
instead build theories around and then get on snopes for it.

comments.text:
I heard someone posted this information on the internet in the early 90's 
as a social experiment. It caught on like wildifre and there was actually a 
book that was published with the information. A year or so later the guys 
(I believe) who porported the ridulous "fact" denounced it claiming their 
prank/experiment because it was getting out of hand but... by then no one 
believee them. However, I believe this was for several spiders "a night" 
not in a year period. Side note: I also remember this phenomenon when I was 
a wee child in the 90s (about 95/96) as a friend of mine explained it to be 
a fact that you swallow spiders at night.... Spiders are my arch-enemy and 
so I refused such statements upon the grounds of incomprehensible for my 
well-being and for fear I'd never sleep again. Also... I tried to assert 
many logical explanations to debunk such a claim... My friend then insisted 
her mom read it in a book.﻿

comments.author: Douglas Smith

comments.text:
What I had heard was the origin of this myth was that it was actually from 
a printed book.  It was a book explicitly talking about debunking myths 
and/or how people will believe things that are not true.
In an interesting way to demonstrate what they were talking about, they 
created the spider myth, declaring it to be true.  And people being who 
they are, started perpetuating the myth from there.

I don't know if it is true or not, that's just what I heard.﻿

I have heard, again no clear source, that the spider rumour was 
deliberately started as part of a study on the spread of urban myths. a 
group of students went home for the summer and each told 3 people then 
returned to uni and waited until someone told it to them. I have heard this 
from a couple of different people at the university of Kent but can find no 
corresponding write up in there online library.﻿

1. Colin Gregory Palmer Grey is his real name, and he just didn't care if 
people knew since, with his increasing popularity, it's only a matter of 
time before he becomes a fairly public face anyway.

2. Colin Gregory Palmer Grey is a pseudonym, and he put that there to f*ck 
with the people that noticed it.

3. He didn't notice due to a severe lack of sleep, which seems unlikely 
since everyone knows Grey is a machine who needs no sleep.

So which is it, +CGP Grey ?﻿

comments.author: 8bitslime

comments.text:
I can definitely say that there seem to be spiders to go for something, 
whether it be your ugly face, movements, or the ability to see or sense 
body heat, I couldn't say. On two occasions I had a spider (assumably the 
same species, I didn't care to examine closely) rope down directly above me 
from the ceiling. One might faintly imagine Lemming spiders.

On the first occasion, I spotted the spider in the corner of the room, no 
farther than 2 metres in a direct line away. Since spiders are not really 
appealing to me, I decided to *take care of it in a minute*, and continued 
working. Though in a minute, the spider had made its way across the ceiling 
and did *rope* down to in front, and a little up of my face.

It's not funny if you have arachnophobia. While being more grossed out than 
being frightened, I guess.

So the thought of swallowing spiders in your sleep, at least some species, 
doesn't seem too far fetched. Unfortunately.﻿
comments.author: jackd23

comments.text:
I know this sounds like absolute s***, I was in my house, and I found a 
small, blackish spider in my bedroom. I thought nothing of it, and went to 
sleep. After waking up, I looked for the spider and I couldn't find it. I 
later got an ultra sound because I have some fluid near my stomach. They 
doctors got worried when they got all the pictures, because there was a 
strange animal in my stomach I didn't know about. After I saw the pictures, 
it look roughly like the spider and two other creatures that I have no clue 
were. They were worried again and gave me some ipecac and we found that 
there was a spider in my stomach. So, in conclusion, I have no doubt that 
spiders love warm, moist places and that a human may swallow on or two or 
many a year, but I truly have no clue if a human swallows 8+ spiders a 
year, but I wouldn't be surprised if it's true.﻿

results.﻿

comments.text:
I remember hearing that In the Marvel comic book world there is a 
fictitious comic creator named Manny Hands.  Good ol' Manny is credited 
with inking and or coloring a ton of comics in the 90s.  The reality being, 
when a comic was running behind schedule  they would get a bunch of artists 
in the bullpen to ink pages, and needing to credit an inker later it was 
easier to just credit Manny (many people) Hands (inking hands).﻿

comments.author: Dominic Eicher

comments.text:
The spider thing is just a myth to scare arachnophobes. Spiders are 
intelligent creatures. When you come across a spider by surprise it will do 
one of two things: it will either freeze in place and hope you don't see it 
or if there is a spot that you can't access it will try to run to that 
area. Whatever happens it's clear that Mr. Spider doesn't want to go about 
his business because he's identified you as titanic monster; and from his 
perspective you are. If Mr. Spider is capable of identifying you and if 
it's clear that he is scared of you he certainly wouldn't try to crawl into 
your mouth when your sleeping.﻿

comments.author: Deliciousbutter

comments.text:
There's usually a pretty comprehensive campaign to laugh at the people who 
made the mistake of believing it when that happens. A great example would 
be articles on dihydrogen monoxide. People claimed that it's a chemical 
that's highly addictive, can kill someone, has ties in all sorts of medical 
problems including cancer, and is routinely dumped into rivers and streams 
by factories with no regulation. I'll let you look up dihydrogen monoxide 
but, suffice it to say that while all those facts are entirely true, it's 
something absolutely hilarious considering the levels of public attention 
it received.
